overview_of_class: In this course, we will study some of the major figures in early analytic philosophy. The basic orientation of the course is systematic, although the historical emergence of the ideas will structure the order of studying the figures in the seminar. The main systematic themes are the idea to solve traditional problems of modern philosophy by elucidation and logical and linguistic analysis, which yields the basic features associated with the linguistic turn in philosophical methodology. Another theme is the ?naturalizing' idea that the role of philosophy is that of at most a partner (if not a part) of science. The leading question tying it all together will be how the notion of what it is to be meaningful and representing the world changed throughout a stepwise process of philosophical elucidation. This course aims at illustrating how analysis first transformed genuinely philosophical problems and issues into linguistic and logical ones and so made them accessible to human (as opposed to transcendent) reason and thereby ultimately resulted in a revolutionary and promising reconception of what it takes for human beings to correctly represent, know and act within the world.
name: Classics of Analytic Philosophy
subject: PHIL
